data.text: Lagarde: Second, it will help guide us towards the Europe we want to build after the crisis. We have been given a chance to take a leap forward: to reimagine our social contract, reconsider Europe’s strategic autonomy & recognise the risks of not taking the environment seriously

Lagarde: First, a common fiscal response will help bridge the gap for Member States and counter that risk of divergence. Given the fiscal needs already on the horizon, it needs to be swift, sizeable and symmetrical.

Lagarde: Not all countries have to react in the same way. But each needs to be able to respond as necessary. Otherwise, we risk widening asymmetries and exiting this crisis with greater economic divergence. This underscores why a common European fiscal response is so desirable.
Lagarde: The ECB will play its part in line with its mandate. We will do everything necessary within our mandate to support the recovery and deliver on our price stability objective.

Lagarde: When it is safe to do so, Europe will have to move to the next phase of its crisis response. The focus will need to shift from providing backstop support to enabling the recovery. This will present a new set of challenges.

Lagarde: The coronavirus pandemic today is both confirming and testing this thesis. We are seeing once more how interdependent we have become. If not all countries are cured from this crisis, the others will suffer – and not just in terms of health, but economically too.
Lagarde: And when the euro members recognised that the single currency was vulnerable to self-fulfilling crises, new institutions were established and new instruments were developed.

Lagarde: By and large, this is the path that integration has followed. When Europeans saw that the common market was not delivering, we launched the Single Market. When we realised the Single Market was vulnerable to competitive devaluations, we launched the euro.

Lagarde: Schuman’s idea was that Europe needed to become so deeply integrated – and so interdependent – that solidarity would become self-interest. And, thereafter, it would become natural to build stronger common institutions that reflected the depth of those ties.

[THREAD] In an address at the online State of the Union Conference, President Christine Lagarde reflects on the 75th anniversary of the end of the Second World War in Europe and the 70th anniversary of the Schuman Declaration.

Coming up in 15 mins: ECB President Christine @Lagarde speaks at the European University Institute’s online State of the Union Conference. Follow live from 13:00 CET https://t.co/BKsC9AHPhU #SOUCOVID19 https://t.co/SB2junsyJ6
SMEs’ expectations about the future availability of external finance fell significantly, in anticipation of the impact of the coronavirus pandemic (4/4) https://t.co/18UTMw01R2
The improvement in SMEs’ access to finance slowed despite lower bank interest rates. Impeding factors were SMEs’ own financial situations and the general economic outlook (3/4)
SMEs reported a decline in turnovers for the first time since 2014, and profits fell across sectors and countries (2/4)

[THREAD] The latest SAFE survey results reveal a clear deterioration in the economic environment for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). The impact of the coronavirus pandemic weighs heavily on expectations for the future (1/4) https://t.co/Jo2CheVXmY

Our Annual Report for 2019 is now available in 22 languages. https://t.co/0gYdW26NlG 
#economics #annualreport #ecb https://t.co/OqNqjY59s4
Key to advancing the recovery is the Single Market, which should be strengthened and deepened. Progress in creating the capital markets union is crucial https://t.co/nLbkFjyN4M

To ensure a strong response, all policy areas should reinforce each other. This necessitates sufficiently forceful fiscal measures in all countries and a political agreement to build instruments for a common response.

The crisis caused euro area financial markets to tighten sharply and volatility to increase greatly. While the financial system has overall weathered the turmoil, vulnerabilities remain and it will be crucial that banks remain as robust as possible and address their weaknesses.

The ECB’s decisive policy measures have provided crucial support to the economy, notably to the sectors most exposed to the crisis. We constantly monitor the situation, remain determined to ensure supportive financial conditions and stand ready to make further policy adjustments.

The EU economy is facing an extraordinary contraction, said ECB Vice-President Luis de Guindos, speaking to the European Parliament’s Economic and Monetary Affairs Committee. Initial estimates point to a 3.8% fall in the euro area economy in Q1, and in Q2 the fall will be deeper. https://t.co/J75zgHkMji

Global stablecoins would need a robust regulatory framework as they could pose a risk to financial stability. Read more https://t.co/mdfAGS2LZm https://t.co/Z5yApMJxC9

Enria: We should closely observe how the crisis is affecting our efforts to complete the banking union. A national bias in policy responses would make it more difficult to manage the crisis and would slow the recovery once we have come through the worst https://t.co/TUyBVBziig

Enria: To understand how the crisis affects banks and where the greatest risks lie, we are now conducting an analysis of banks’ vulnerabilities. Also, the supervisory review process will focus on the risks for banks and their ability to manage them effectively.
Enria: The first goal of ECB Banking Supervision has been to ensure banks can contribute to the recovery from this crisis by continuing to finance households and businesses.

The measures taken by EU and national authorities form a coherent package which will support the economy in the transition to recovery after the coronavirus shock, ECB Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria said to the European Parliament’s Economic and Monetary Affairs Committee. https://t.co/WDOwUcuIhW

Panetta: We provide crucial infrastructures for the European financial system: the TARGET2-Securities (T2S) service has handled smoothly the very high trade volumes in European bonds and shares in the recent market turbulence. Full blog post here https://t.co/qR9H6FxrNX https://t.co/uifb76rQnm

Panetta: We are assessing the case for issuing a “digital euro”. We also aim to foster European market solutions for payments online and in brick-and-mortar shops. And we work to contain cyber risks, together with other European institutions.

Panetta: The coronavirus crisis also reinforces the demand for electronic payments. The Eurosystem has always been at the forefront of efforts to facilitate innovative payment solutions for Europeans, such as instant payments. And we continue our work in these difficult times.

Panetta: The ECB and the 19 euro area national central banks are well-prepared to ensure the continued availability of banknotes: we plan the activities related to the cash supply chain well in advance, adapt our processes continually and hold a strategic contingency stock.

Panetta: The crisis has made demand for cash less predictable. In mid-March it spiked, reflecting higher spending ahead of lockdowns and an impulse to hoard cash. In April cash demand decreased as confinement reduced spending opportunities.

Ensuring people and firms can continue to make payments safely is an important part of our mission, writes Executive Board member Fabio Panetta in a blog post. It is vital not only for monetary policy but also for Europeans’ daily lives https://t.co/5INM6rNNnB #TheECBBlog https://t.co/m7A9cFgmXM

Acting now will help all member countries shorten the duration of the crisis period. It will protect the economic base upon which their future production structures and exports rely, and uphold the promise of a shared and indivisible European destiny 7/7 https://t.co/2tKlpyjxba

Whichever funding model is chosen, the goal of fiscal policy must be to push the financing costs of this crisis very far into the future. European issuance today will create the fiscal policy space needed to secure higher growth in the future 6/7

A European fiscal response must be based on 3 principles:
- the size should be proportionate to the shock’s magnitude
- it should not aggravate fragmentation stemming from differences in initial fiscal positions
- it should not skew the playing field within the Single Market 5/7

There’s also the risk of political spillovers. Any perception that common action is absent now would dilute public support for the EU, which is already visible in countries on the frontline of the health crisis. Ultimately, this perception could erode trust in euro 4/7

Today’s crisis exacerbates these dynamics in two ways: the global nature of the shock means European countries cannot redirect their production to satisfy demand from elsewhere, while high participation rates of eurozone firms in global value chains will amplify the shock 3/7

Eurozone economies are tightly interlinked through supply chains, financial connections and trade relationships. As a result, a slump in a large part of the eurozone will depress growth and employment across the entire region 2/7

A forceful, symmetric European response is needed, ECB Executive Board member Fabio Panetta writes in @POLITICOEurope. Failure to act now will amplify the costs of the crisis. It will also weaken the policy responses already being undertaken 1/7 https://t.co/2tKlpyjxba https://t.co/tcFjZ7pswp
Enria: I really urge all market participants to let the banks actually use these buffers as they’re supposed to.

We are not turning back the clock in terms of the rigour of the conservative regulatory framework, says Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria. We apply the regulatory framework by releasing those buffers that were supposed to be used in difficult times https://t.co/M5i1c4H897 https://t.co/G4WgIMfTaY
